short_description: Oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells
interpretation_summary: Low Hb causes anaemia (fatigue, pallor). High Hb may indicate polycythaemia or dehydration.

aliases: total wbc count,wbc count,wbc,total leucocyte count,tlc,leukocyte count,white blood cell count,total white blood cell count,total wbc
short_description: Total white blood cell count; immune system activity indicator
interpretation_summary: Elevated WBC suggests infection or inflammation. Low WBC (leukopenia) indicates immunosuppression.

short_description: Cell fragments essential for blood clotting
interpretation_summary: Low platelets (thrombocytopenia) risk bleeding. High platelets (thrombocytosis) may indicate clotting risk.

aliases: total rbc count,rbc count,rbc,red blood cell count,red cell count,erythrocyte count,total rbc
short_description: Number of red blood cells per volume of blood
interpretation_summary: Low RBC causes anaemia. High RBC may suggest polycythaemia.

short_description: Percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells
interpretation_summary: Reflects red cell mass. Low values indicate anaemia; high values suggest dehydration or polycythaemia.

aliases: mcv,mean corpuscular volume,mean cell volume,mean corp. volume
short_description: Average volume of red blood cells
interpretation_summary: Low MCV = microcytic (iron deficiency). High MCV = macrocytic (B12/folate deficiency).

aliases: mch,mean corpuscular hemoglobin,mean corpuscular haemoglobin,mean cell hemoglobin
short_description: Average haemoglobin per red blood cell
interpretation_summary: Low MCH indicates hypochromic anaemia. High MCH suggests macrocytosis.

aliases: mchc,mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration,mean cell hemoglobin concentration
short_description: Haemoglobin concentration in red blood cells
interpretation_summary: Low MCHC indicates iron deficiency. High MCHC may suggest hereditary spherocytosis.

short_description: Variability in red blood cell size
interpretation_summary: Elevated RDW indicates anisocytosis; seen in iron deficiency, B12 deficiency, and mixed anaemias.

aliases: absolute neutrophil count,abs. neutrophil count,abs neutrophil count,absolute neutrophils,anc,neutrophil - absolute,neutrophils absolute,abs.neutrophil count
short_description: Absolute count of neutrophils; primary bacterial infection fighters
interpretation_summary: Low ANC (neutropenia) increases infection risk. High ANC suggests bacterial infection or stress.

short_description: Percentage of WBCs that are neutrophils
interpretation_summary: Elevated neutrophils indicate bacterial infection. Low levels suggest viral infection or bone marrow suppression.

aliases: absolute lymphocyte count,abs. lymphocyte count,abs lymphocyte count,absolute lymphocytes,alc,lymphocyte - absolute,lymphocytes absolute
short_description: Absolute lymphocyte count; key immune cells
interpretation_summary: Low lymphocytes (lymphopenia) seen in viral infections and immunosuppression. High values in viral or lymphocytic leukaemia.

short_description: Percentage of WBCs that are lymphocytes
interpretation_summary: Elevated in viral infections; decreased in HIV, steroid use, and lymphopenia.

aliases: absolute monocyte count,abs. monocyte count,abs monocyte count,absolute monocytes,amc,monocyte - absolute,monocytes absolute
short_description: Absolute monocyte count; first-line immune defence
interpretation_summary: Elevated monocytes seen in chronic infections, autoimmune conditions, and monocytic leukaemia.

short_description: Percentage of WBCs that are monocytes
interpretation_summary: Elevated monocytes suggest chronic infection or inflammatory disease.

aliases: absolute eosinophil count,abs. eosinophil count,abs eosinophil count,absolute eosinophils,aec,eosinophil - absolute,eosinophils absolute
short_description: Absolute eosinophil count; involved in allergy and parasitic response
interpretation_summary: Elevated eosinophils (eosinophilia) seen in allergies, asthma, parasitic infections.

short_description: Percentage of WBCs that are eosinophils
interpretation_summary: High eosinophils suggest allergy, asthma, or parasitic infection.

aliases: absolute basophil count,abs. basophil count,abs basophil count,absolute basophils,abc,basophil - absolute,basophils absolute
short_description: Absolute basophil count; least common WBC
interpretation_summary: Rarely clinically significant alone. Elevated in myeloproliferative disorders and hypothyroidism.

short_description: Percentage of WBCs that are basophils
interpretation_summary: Very rarely elevated; basophilia seen in haematological malignancies.

short_description: Iron circulating in the blood
interpretation_summary: Low serum iron confirms iron deficiency. High levels seen in haemochromatosis or iron overload.

short_description: Maximum amount of iron the blood can carry
interpretation_summary: High TIBC seen in iron deficiency. Low TIBC in iron overload, inflammation, or malnutrition.

short_description: Percentage of transferrin saturated with iron
interpretation_summary: Low saturation indicates iron deficiency. High saturation (>70%) suggests iron overload or haemochromatosis.

short_description: Iron storage protein; reflects total body iron stores
interpretation_summary: Low ferritin is the earliest marker of iron deficiency. High ferritin indicates iron overload or inflammation.

short_description: Total blood cholesterol level
interpretation_summary: Elevated total cholesterol increases cardiovascular risk. Optimal is below 170 mg/dL.

short_description: 'Good' cholesterol that removes other forms from bloodstream
interpretation_summary: High HDL is protective against heart disease. Low HDL increases cardiovascular risk.

short_description: 'Bad' cholesterol that can build up in arteries
interpretation_summary: LDL is a primary target of cholesterol-lowering therapy. Below 100 is optimal; above 160 is high risk.

short_description: Blood fats linked to diet, obesity, and metabolic syndrome
interpretation_summary: Elevated triglycerides indicate metabolic syndrome and pancreatitis risk. Very high levels (>500) are critical.

short_description: Lipoprotein carrying triglycerides from liver
interpretation_summary: Elevated VLDL linked to hypertriglyceridaemia and cardiovascular risk.

aliases: non hdl cholesterol,non-hdl cholesterol,non hdl-c,non hdl,non-hdl
short_description: Total cholesterol minus HDL; includes all atherogenic particles
interpretation_summary: Better predictor of cardiovascular risk than LDL alone. Target below 130 mg/dL.

short_description: Main protein in HDL; reflects reverse cholesterol transport capacity
interpretation_summary: Low ApoA1 is associated with increased cardiovascular risk. High levels are cardioprotective.

aliases: apo lipoprotein b,apolipoproteins b,apo b,apolipoprotein b,apob,apo-b
short_description: Main protein in LDL; counts all atherogenic particles
interpretation_summary: ApoB is a better predictor of cardiovascular risk than LDL-C. High levels indicate increased risk.

short_description: Lipoprotein involved in lipid transport and Alzheimer's risk (APOE4)
interpretation_summary: ApoE genotype influences cholesterol metabolism. APOE4 allele increases Alzheimer's and cardiovascular risk.

short_description: Independent cardiovascular risk factor not affected by lifestyle
interpretation_summary: Elevated Lp(a) is genetic and significantly increases risk of heart attack and stroke.

short_description: Liver enzyme released during liver cell damage
interpretation_summary: Elevated AST indicates liver damage, heart attack, or muscle injury. Very high levels suggest acute hepatitis.

short_description: Liver-specific enzyme; most sensitive marker of liver damage
interpretation_summary: Elevated ALT is the most specific marker of hepatocellular injury. High levels indicate viral hepatitis or NAFLD.

short_description: Enzyme from liver, bone, and bile ducts
interpretation_summary: Elevated ALP seen in liver disease, bile duct obstruction, or bone disease. Isolated elevation suggests bone origin.

aliases: gamma gt ( ggtp),gamma gt (ggtp),ggt,ggtp,gamma glutamyl transferase,gamma glutamyl transpeptidase,gamma-gt
short_description: Enzyme indicating bile duct disease or alcohol use
interpretation_summary: Elevated GGT is sensitive for liver disease and alcohol use. Often elevated with ALP in cholestatic disease.

short_description: Breakdown product of red blood cells processed by liver
interpretation_summary: Elevated bilirubin causes jaundice. High levels indicate liver disease, bile duct obstruction, or haemolysis.

short_description: Conjugated bilirubin from liver; elevated in cholestatic disease
interpretation_summary: Elevated direct bilirubin indicates bile duct obstruction or hepatocellular disease.

short_description: Unconjugated bilirubin from RBC breakdown; elevated in haemolysis
interpretation_summary: Elevated indirect bilirubin suggests haemolysis or Gilbert's syndrome.

short_description: Main protein made by liver; reflects liver synthetic function
interpretation_summary: Low albumin indicates poor liver synthetic function, malnutrition, or protein loss. High in dehydration.

aliases: total proteins,total protein,s.total protein,serum total protein,tp
short_description: Sum of albumin and globulins in blood
interpretation_summary: Low total protein suggests malnutrition or liver disease. High levels seen in multiple myeloma.

short_description: Immune and transport proteins in blood
interpretation_summary: Elevated globulin suggests chronic infection, autoimmune disease, or multiple myeloma.

aliases: a/g ratio,albumin globulin ratio,ag ratio,a:g ratio
short_description: Ratio of albumin to globulin; indicator of liver and immune function
interpretation_summary: Low A/G ratio suggests elevated globulins (infection, autoimmunity) or low albumin (liver disease).

aliases: urea - serum,urea,blood urea,blood urea nitrogen,bun,serum urea,urea (serum)
short_description: Nitrogen waste from protein metabolism cleared by kidneys
interpretation_summary: Elevated urea indicates reduced kidney function or increased protein catabolism. Low levels seen in liver disease.

short_description: Muscle waste product; primary marker of kidney filtration
interpretation_summary: Elevated creatinine indicates reduced GFR. Levels >2.0 suggest significant kidney impairment.

short_description: Estimated kidney filtration rate
interpretation_summary: eGFR below 60 indicates chronic kidney disease (CKD). Below 15 is kidney failure requiring dialysis.

aliases: uric acid,serum uric acid,s.uric acid,urate,uric acid (serum)
short_description: End product of purine metabolism; elevated in gout
interpretation_summary: Elevated uric acid causes gout and kidney stones. High levels linked to hypertension and metabolic syndrome.

short_description: Small amounts of albumin in urine; early kidney damage marker
interpretation_summary: Microalbuminuria is the earliest sign of diabetic nephropathy and hypertensive kidney damage.

short_description: Creatinine excreted in urine; used for normalisation of urine tests
interpretation_summary: Used to calculate albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR) for kidney assessment.

aliases: tsh,thyroid stimulating hormone,thyrotropin,s.tsh,tsh 3rd generation (hs tsh),tsh (hs tsh),hs tsh,tsh 3rd generation,tsh- 3rd generation (hs tsh)
short_description: Pituitary hormone that stimulates thyroid; primary screening test
interpretation_summary: High TSH indicates hypothyroidism. Low TSH (suppressed) indicates hyperthyroidism. Optimal is 0.5â2.5 mIU/L.

short_description: Active form of thyroid hormone; reflects tissue thyroid activity
interpretation_summary: Low FT3 seen in hypothyroidism or non-thyroidal illness. High FT3 indicates hyperthyroidism.

short_description: Inactive thyroid hormone converted to T3 in tissues
interpretation_summary: Low FT4 with high TSH confirms hypothyroidism. High FT4 with low TSH confirms hyperthyroidism.

short_description: Total circulating T3 (bound + free); reflects overall thyroid output
interpretation_summary: Elevated in hyperthyroidism; reduced in hypothyroidism and sick euthyroid syndrome.

short_description: Total circulating T4; reflects thyroid hormone production
interpretation_summary: Elevated in hyperthyroidism; reduced in hypothyroidism.

aliases: anti-tpo,tpo antibody,thyroid peroxidase antibody,anti tpo ab,thyroid antibody,anti tpo,tpo ab
short_description: Autoantibody attacking thyroid; marker of autoimmune thyroid disease
interpretation_summary: Elevated anti-TPO indicates Hashimoto's thyroiditis or Graves' disease. High levels predict hypothyroidism progression.

short_description: Autoantibody against thyroglobulin; marker of autoimmune thyroid disease
interpretation_summary: Elevated in Hashimoto's thyroiditis and thyroid cancer follow-up.

aliases: glucose (fasting),glucose fasting (plasma-f,hexokinase),glucose fasting,fasting blood sugar,fbs,fasting glucose,blood glucose fasting,fasting plasma glucose
short_description: Blood sugar level after 8-hour fast; primary diabetes screening test
interpretation_summary: 100â125 mg/dL = prediabetes. â¥126 mg/dL = diabetes. Below 70 = hypoglycaemia.

aliases: pp glucose,post prandial glucose,pbg,glucose post prandial,pp blood sugar,2hr pp glucose,2 hr pp glucose,postprandial glucose
short_description: Blood sugar 2 hours after a meal
interpretation_summary: â¥200 mg/dL (2hr PP) indicates diabetes. 140â199 is impaired glucose tolerance (prediabetes).

aliases: hba1c,hb a1c,hba1c- glycated haemoglobin,hba1c- glycated haemoglobin (hplc),glycated haemoglobin,hba1c- glycated haemoglobin, blood by hplc method,glycohaemoglobin,glycosylated haemoglobin,a1c,hemoglobin a1c
short_description: 3-month average blood sugar; gold standard for diabetes monitoring
interpretation_summary: 5.7â6.4% = prediabetes. â¥6.5% = diabetes. Target for diabetics is usually below 7%.

short_description: Pancreatic hormone controlling blood sugar
interpretation_summary: High fasting insulin suggests insulin resistance. Very high levels seen in insulinoma.

short_description: By-product of insulin production; measures beta-cell function
interpretation_summary: Low C-peptide in Type 1 diabetes. High levels in Type 2 or insulinoma.

aliases: vitamin d (25-oh),25 hydroxy (oh) vit d,25-oh vitamin d,vitamin d,25 oh vitamin d,25(oh)d,25-hydroxyvitamin d,25 oh vitamin d3,vitamin d3
short_description: Fat-soluble vitamin essential for calcium absorption and immunity
interpretation_summary: Deficiency (<20 ng/mL) linked to bone loss, immunity, and mood disorders. Toxicity above 150 ng/mL.

short_description: Essential vitamin for nerve function and DNA synthesis
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia and neuropathy. Common in vegetarians and elderly.

short_description: B-vitamin essential for DNA synthesis and cell division
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia and neural tube defects. Important in pregnancy.

short_description: Fat-soluble vitamin essential for vision and immunity
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes night blindness. Toxicity (hypervitaminosis A) from excessive supplementation.

short_description: Fat-soluble antioxidant vitamin
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes neuropathy and haemolytic anaemia. Toxicity can occur with excessive supplementation.

short_description: Mineral essential for bone, muscle, and nerve function
interpretation_summary: Low calcium (hypocalcaemia) causes muscle cramps and tetany. High calcium (hypercalcaemia) suggests hyperparathyroidism.

short_description: Mineral involved in over 300 enzyme reactions
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes muscle cramps, arrhythmias, and anxiety. Common in diabetes and alcoholism.

short_description: Mineral essential for bone formation and energy metabolism
interpretation_summary: Elevated phosphate seen in kidney disease. Low phosphate in malabsorption or hyperparathyroidism.

short_description: Essential trace element for immunity and wound healing
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes impaired immunity, poor wound healing, and taste abnormalities.

short_description: Trace element for iron metabolism and nerve function
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes anaemia. Elevated in Wilson's disease or chronic liver disease.

short_description: Rate of red cell settling; non-specific marker of inflammation
interpretation_summary: Elevated ESR indicates inflammation, infection, or autoimmune disease. Very high levels in multiple myeloma.

short_description: Acute-phase protein produced in response to inflammation
interpretation_summary: Elevated CRP indicates infection or inflammation. Does not specify cause. Useful for monitoring treatment response.

aliases: hscrp,hs-crp,hs crp,c reactive protein (hs),high sensitivity crp,high sensitivity c reactive protein,c-reactive protein (high sensitivity)
short_description: Ultra-sensitive CRP test for cardiovascular risk assessment
interpretation_summary: Below 1 mg/L: low CV risk. 1â3 mg/L: intermediate. Above 3 mg/L: high cardiovascular risk.

short_description: Biomarker that rises specifically in bacterial infection and sepsis
interpretation_summary: Above 0.5 ng/mL suggests bacterial infection. Above 2 ng/mL indicates high risk of sepsis.

short_description: Inflammatory cytokine; elevated in infection, autoimmune disease, and cytokine storm
interpretation_summary: Markedly elevated in COVID-19 cytokine storm, sepsis, and autoimmune conditions.

short_description: Primary male sex hormone
interpretation_summary: Low testosterone causes hypogonadism (fatigue, low libido, reduced muscle mass). High levels seen in testosterone therapy or tumours.

short_description: Testosterone in women; important for libido and bone density
interpretation_summary: High testosterone in women causes PCOS, hirsutism, and acne. Low levels cause fatigue and low libido.

short_description: Biologically active unbound testosterone
interpretation_summary: More clinically relevant than total testosterone. Low free T causes hypogonadism symptoms even with normal total T.

short_description: Primary female sex hormone; drives reproductive development
interpretation_summary: Low estradiol causes menopause symptoms, bone loss. High levels in PCOS, ovarian tumours, or exogenous oestrogen.

short_description: Hormone that prepares uterus for pregnancy after ovulation
interpretation_summary: Low mid-luteal progesterone suggests anovulation. Used to confirm ovulation occurred (>10 ng/mL at day 21).

short_description: Pituitary hormone regulating reproductive development
interpretation_summary: High FSH in women indicates diminished ovarian reserve or menopause. In men, high FSH suggests testicular failure.

short_description: Pituitary hormone triggering ovulation in women and testosterone in men
interpretation_summary: Elevated LH with high FSH indicates primary hypogonadism. Mid-cycle LH surge triggers ovulation.

short_description: Hormone from pituitary; primarily involved in lactation
interpretation_summary: Elevated prolactin (hyperprolactinaemia) causes menstrual irregularity, galactorrhoea, and infertility.

short_description: Androgen precursor from adrenal glands; declines with age
interpretation_summary: Low DHEA-S is associated with adrenal insufficiency and ageing. High levels seen in adrenal tumours and PCOS.

short_description: Stress hormone from adrenal glands; collected in morning
interpretation_summary: High cortisol suggests Cushing's syndrome. Low cortisol indicates adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease).

aliases: igf - i,igf i,igf-1,igf1,igf i (somatomedin c),igf-i,insulin-like growth factor 1,somatomedin c
short_description: Growth factor reflecting growth hormone activity
interpretation_summary: Elevated in acromegaly. Low in growth hormone deficiency, malnutrition, and liver disease.

short_description: Marker of ovarian reserve; predicts fertility potential
interpretation_summary: Low AMH indicates diminished ovarian reserve. High AMH seen in PCOS or ovarian hyperstimulation.

short_description: Highly specific marker of heart muscle damage
interpretation_summary: Any elevation above 0.04 ng/mL suggests acute myocardial injury. Used to diagnose heart attack.

short_description: Hormone released by heart under pressure; marker of heart failure
interpretation_summary: BNP above 400 pg/mL indicates heart failure. Used to distinguish cardiac from non-cardiac dyspnoea.

short_description: More stable form of BNP; superior heart failure marker
interpretation_summary: Above 125 pg/mL suggests cardiac stress. Above 900 indicates significant heart failure.

short_description: Cardiac-specific creatine kinase isoenzyme
interpretation_summary: Elevated in myocardial infarction. Rises 3â6 hours after MI and peaks at 12â24 hours.

short_description: Enzyme found in many tissues; elevated in tissue damage
interpretation_summary: Non-specific but elevated in MI, haemolysis, liver disease, and malignancy.

short_description: Time for blood to clot via extrinsic pathway
interpretation_summary: Elevated PT indicates anticoagulation therapy, liver disease, or vitamin K deficiency.

short_description: Standardised measure of clotting time
interpretation_summary: INR 2â3 is therapeutic for anticoagulation. Above 4 increases bleeding risk significantly.

short_description: Measures intrinsic pathway of coagulation
interpretation_summary: Prolonged APTT seen with heparin therapy, haemophilia, or lupus anticoagulant.

short_description: Fibrin breakdown product; elevated in thrombosis
interpretation_summary: Elevated D-dimer suggests DVT, PE, or DIC. High sensitivity but low specificity.

short_description: Clotting protein from liver; also an acute phase reactant
interpretation_summary: Elevated in infection and inflammation. Low fibrinogen seen in DIC and liver failure.

short_description: Screening test for autoimmune disease
interpretation_summary: Positive ANA requires follow-up with specific antibodies (anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm). Present in 15% of normal population.

short_description: Antibody specific to lupus (SLE)
interpretation_summary: Highly specific for SLE. Levels correlate with disease activity and lupus nephritis.

short_description: Autoantibody associated with rheumatoid arthritis
interpretation_summary: Elevated RF seen in RA, SjÃ¶gren's syndrome, and other autoimmune conditions. Not specific to RA.

short_description: Highly specific antibody for rheumatoid arthritis
interpretation_summary: Anti-CCP is more specific than RF for RA diagnosis and can be positive before symptoms.

aliases: anti sperm antibody,anti-sperm antibody,asa,antisperm antibodies,anti-sperm antibodies
short_description: Antibodies against sperm; cause of immunological infertility
interpretation_summary: Positive ASA can impair sperm function, motility, and fertilisation. Relevant investigation in infertility.

short_description: Antibody associated with allergic responses
interpretation_summary: Elevated total IgE indicates atopy or parasitic infection. Very high levels in allergic asthma and eczema.

short_description: Most abundant antibody; primary immune defence
interpretation_summary: Low IgG indicates immunodeficiency. High IgG seen in chronic infections and autoimmune disease.

short_description: Antibody protecting mucosal surfaces
interpretation_summary: Low IgA (IgA deficiency) causes recurrent respiratory infections. High IgA seen in liver disease.

short_description: First antibody produced in infection; marker of acute infection
interpretation_summary: Elevated IgM indicates acute infection or primary immune response. Low in some immunodeficiencies.

short_description: Enzyme from pancreas and salivary glands
interpretation_summary: Elevated amylase in pancreatitis, bowel obstruction, and salivary gland disease.

short_description: Pancreatic enzyme that breaks down fats; more specific than amylase
interpretation_summary: Elevated lipase is more specific for pancreatitis than amylase. Remains elevated longer.

short_description: Prostate-specific marker for prostate cancer screening
interpretation_summary: PSA 4â10 ng/mL: grey zone requiring biopsy consideration. Above 10: high risk of prostate cancer.

short_description: Tumour marker for colorectal and other GI cancers
interpretation_summary: Elevated in colorectal, lung, breast cancers. Also raised in smokers and inflammatory bowel disease.

short_description: Tumour marker for liver cancer and testicular germ cell tumours
interpretation_summary: Elevated AFP indicates hepatocellular carcinoma or testicular cancer. Very elevated in liver cancer.

short_description: Tumour marker for ovarian cancer; also elevated in endometriosis
interpretation_summary: CA-125 above 35 is suspicious for ovarian cancer. High levels in endometriosis, fibroids, and ascites.

short_description: Tumour marker for pancreatic and gastrointestinal cancers
interpretation_summary: Elevated in pancreatic cancer, cholangiocarcinoma, and GI malignancies.

short_description: Pregnancy hormone; tumour marker for germ cell tumours
interpretation_summary: Elevated in pregnancy and germ cell tumours (testicular and ovarian). Used for tumour follow-up.

short_description: Primary extracellular electrolyte; controls fluid balance
interpretation_summary: Hyponatraemia (<135) causes confusion and seizures. Hypernatraemia (>145) indicates dehydration.

short_description: Electrolyte critical for heart and muscle function
interpretation_summary: Hypokalaemia causes muscle weakness and cardiac arrhythmias. Hyperkalaemia is a medical emergency.

short_description: Electrolyte working with sodium to maintain fluid balance
interpretation_summary: Hyperchloraemia seen with dehydration. Hypochloraemia seen with prolonged vomiting.

short_description: Buffer electrolyte reflecting acid-base balance
interpretation_summary: Low bicarbonate indicates metabolic acidosis. High levels indicate metabolic alkalosis.

short_description: Acidity or alkalinity of urine
interpretation_summary: Acidic urine in high protein diet or acidosis. Alkaline urine in UTI or alkalosis.

short_description: Protein in urine; marker of kidney damage
interpretation_summary: Persistent proteinuria indicates kidney disease. Heavy proteinuria (>3.5g/day) = nephrotic syndrome.

short_description: Amino acid linked to cardiovascular risk and B12/folate deficiency
interpretation_summary: Elevated homocysteine is an independent cardiovascular risk factor. Reduced by B12, folate, and B6.

short_description: Enzyme from muscle and heart; released during muscle damage
interpretation_summary: Elevated CK indicates muscle injury, rhabdomyolysis, hypothyroidism, or statin myopathy.

short_description: Nitrogen component of blood urea; kidney function marker
interpretation_summary: Elevated BUN with elevated creatinine suggests kidney impairment. Elevated BUN alone may indicate high protein diet.

short_description: Metabolic byproduct; elevated in tissue hypoxia
interpretation_summary: Elevated lactate indicates tissue hypoxia, sepsis, or liver disease. Critically elevated in lactic acidosis.

short_description: Nitrogen waste; elevated in liver failure and hyperammonaemia
interpretation_summary: Elevated ammonia causes hepatic encephalopathy. Critical in liver failure and urea cycle disorders.

short_description: Trace element with antioxidant function
interpretation_summary: Deficiency causes cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) and immune dysfunction.

short_description: Androgen precursor from adrenal glands; free form of DHEA-S
interpretation_summary: Low DHEA associated with adrenal fatigue and ageing. High levels seen in adrenal tumours and PCOS.

short_description: Pituitary hormone promoting growth and metabolism
interpretation_summary: Elevated GH indicates acromegaly or gigantism. Low GH causes growth hormone deficiency.

aliases: dengue ns1 antigen,dengue ns1,ns1 antigen,dengue ns1 ag,dengue antigen
short_description: Dengue fever antigen detected in early infection
interpretation_summary: Positive NS1 antigen confirms early dengue infection (days 1â5 of fever).
